passages.text: FED and LatAm Equities This Timel Different

We continue with our idea that a lot that happens in LatAm is driven by global events. And a big one is coming up, namely the Fed resuming the interest rate cuts that were interrupted in December 2024. In this report, we look back at periods of Fed easing to identify how markets have performed at the time. We look at 5 easing cycles, starting in 1998, as we don't think that before then there was a robust LatAm market to be gauged. The conclusions are not super robust because typically Fed cuts took place during crisis periods and led to a flight to quality to the USD, leading the dollar to appreciate and LatAm currencies to depreciate, leading to higher inflation and higher rates. However, we think that the current cycle is different because it is happening in the context of a soft landing in the US along with a weaker dollar stance, which paves the way for LatAm countries to cut interest rates and have positive equity market returns.

Context of Fed easing: For the past 30 years most of the Fed easing took place in an environment of crisis: LTCM, Russia crisis, 9/11, Dotcom bubble, Global Financial Crisis (2008), Covid. These events typically result in a flight to quality, leading to an appreciation of the US dollar. Also, LatAm countries were undergoing significant turmoil at times of Fed easing, leading countries to actually hike rates as a response to currency depreciation.
Figure 1: Interest Rates and FX Variation in LatAm Countries at Times of Fed Easing
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.; J.P. Morgan. Note: negative sign for currency is an appreciation

Markets do well around first Fed easing: We have had long debates on whether this is the first easing of a cycle or the continuation of the easing cycle that started in September 2024. Still, we thought it was interesting to find out that taking all observed cycles into consideration, markets on average had a good performance in the month before the first cut, in the month of the cut and immediately after that. EM outperforms DM by \(12.4\%\) in this period, Asia does better than LatAm and in LatAm Brazil comes out ahead \((+16.9)\) .

Full cycle performance during the entire Fed easing cycle is typically negative because it encompasses periods of crisis and not the recovery afterwards (once the Fed is on pause). For example, the easing that took place during the Global Financial Crisis ended in December 2008, just 3 months after the Lehman debacle. The trade war / Covid cycle ended in March 2020, which is right when Covid started to take hold of the world. The one big exception is the latest Fed easing cycle where performance is largely positive across assets. We think that this will remain the case. See table and charts inside.
Country views - On the way to the Bull Scenario? In our 2H outlook report we lifted most of our targets for LatAm markets relative to the start of the year

by an average of \(10\%\) . Now, most markets are at or close to the base case scenario, with the exception being Argentina. The question is whether there is more upside. The Fed is certainly capable of delivering that. But beyond that, there are local issues that are starting to weigh more and could become bull triggers by YE: 1) Chile and Argentina elections; 2) Approaching of the easing cycle in Brazil (Dec), not to mention the elections, which we think put a high floor on the Ibov (look how it behaved well during the tariff sanction melee); 3) Start of USMCA negotiations in Mexico. Read about those on the country pages inside. We are OW Brazil; N Mexico and Chile; UW Colombia and Peru. We have a positive view on off- index Argentina.

- Sectors and Stocks: We remain underweight on commodities and OW on domestic cyclical sectors. Despite growth deceleration, inflation is also falling, helping disposable income at the same time that all countries in the region are already cutting rates, with Brazil joining soon. Our largest sector OWs are Real Estate, Financials, Consumer Discretionary and Utilities. On a stock level, we removed Banco do Brasil from our portfolio and added Nubank. Although prices for both have moved a lot already, we feel that BBAS won’t recover soon as the recent large deterioration in agribusiness asset quality is likely to weigh on earnings, profitability and dividend payout. NU, on the other hand, has more upside with the Mexico operation reaching breakeven this year. In Brazil, we also removed Rumo on weak operational prospects and lack of triggers for now. In Mexico, we substituted Arca for Femsa and GCC for Cemex. Femsa is at a very attractive entry point considering the stock remains very cheap despite recent buybacks. Despite the rally on Cemex, we think there is more to go as the company delivers on its cost saving program and new management initiatives. In Chile, we removed CMPC as it trades already in line with JPM target and also doesn’t offer exposure to the country’s two main triggers: elections and higher copper/ lithium prices.

We continue with our idea that a lot that happens in LatAm is driven by global events. And a big one is coming up, namely the Fed resuming the interest rate cuts that were interrupted in December 2024. In this report, we look back at periods of Fed easing to identify how markets have performed at the time. We look into 5 easing cycles, starting in 1998, as we think that before that there wasn't really a robust LatAm/ EM market to be gauged. The conclusions are not super robust because typically Fed cuts took place during crisis periods and led to a flight to quality to the USD, leading the dollar to appreciate and LatAm currencies to depreciate, leading to higher inflation and higher rates. However, we think that the current cycle is different because it is happening in a context of a soft landing in the US along with a weaker dollar stance, which paves the way for LatAm countries to cut interest rates and have positive equity market returns.

Context of easing in the past 20 years was crisis driven: Since 1998, there have been only 5 Fed easing cycles and most of them happened in extraordinary circumstances: 1) Sept 1998 to Nov 1998 was a very short cycle delivering only 75bp of cuts which were reversed only 6 months later. Those cuts were delivered amidst a very negative market environment, coming in response to the Asia crisis (1997), Russia crisis and LTCM (1998). 2) The 2001 cycle came in response to the bursting of the Dotcom bubble and was fueled by the Sept 11 attacks. 3) The 2007- 2008 cycle was on the back of the housing market decline and the subsequent global credit crisis. 4) The 2019- 2020 cycle was first a reaction to the global economic slowdown which was enhanced by the trade war between the US and China. After a small pause, the Fed resumed easing because of the start of the Covid pandemic. 5) The 100bp easing from 2024 was the only one that was actually done in "normal" circumstances, when inflation was declining and there were a few signs of labor market weakness. Its continuation might be associated with the cooling of economic activity because of tariffs.

At times of crisis, the natural move was a flight to quality. All LatAm currencies, with the exception of the PEN, typically depreciate during Fed easing cycles as a result of a flight to quality. However, this time could be different. For the first time since 2014 the USD is weakening, which allows all LatAm markets to continue, resume or start a weakening cycle. It is not the traditional situation where a Fed cut typically leads to LatAm currency depreciation, leading central banks in the region to generally have to hike interest rates, as seen in the table below.

At times of crisis, the natural move was a flight to quality. All LatAm currencies, with the exception of the PEN, typically depreciate during Fed easing cycles as a result of a flight to quality. However, this time could be different. For the first time since 2014 the USD is weakening, which allows all LatAm markets to continue, resume or start a weakening cycle. It is not the traditional situation where a Fed cut typically leads to LatAm currency depreciation, leading central banks in the region to generally have to hike interest rates, as seen in the table below.
Table 3: Interest Rates and FX Variation in LatAm Countries at Times of Fed Easing Negative sign on FX is currency appreciation. Rates variation in bp.
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.; J.P. Morgan. Note: negative sign for currency is an appreciation.

- Our easing forecast for LatAm until YE26: 1) Brazil will cut rates by 425bp starting in December 25, bringing the Selic to \(10.75\%\) ; 2) Mexico will cut an additional 125bp to \(6.50\%\) , for a total cycle of 475bp; 3) Chile should cut rates by an additional 50bp bringing rates to \(4.25\%\) , extending the cycle that started in July 2023 and will result in an easing of 700bp; 4) Colombia will continue the easing that started in December 2023 by cutting an additional 75bp to \(8.5\%\) , bringing the the total easing cycle to 475bp; 5) Even Peru, which has a more stable monetary policy for the PEN tied to the USD, will be cutting an additional 50bp, bringing rates to \(4\%\) and completing a 375bp cut that started in September 2023.
Table 4: Interest Rates Forecasts for LatAm Countries
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.; J.P. Morgan economics

- On aggregate, looking at the past 5 easing cycles, markets overall have a positive performance immediately before and after the first Fed easing took place. EM performs well in the periods around the rate cut, especially in the month of the easing and in the month after it. In both these periods, EM outperforms DM. Within EM, Asia does a lot better than LatAm and CEEMEA. Within LatAm, Peru performs best in the three months before and after the rate cut, perhaps because of its correlation with the USD. However, Brazil is the country that has the best performance around the Fed cut (one month before, during and one month after).
Table 5: Top-down table: region and country aggregate performance around the first Fed cut
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.; J.P. Morgan. Note: 1) Negative sign for Broad USD and DXY is a depreciation. 2) Table considers the past 5 easing cycles. Exact dates can be found in Table 2.

- However, looking at individual cycles in LatAm, there is not a clear performance pattern around the first easing. On average, markets do well 1 month before the easing and in the month of the easing. Positive performance remains in place for the 2 months following the easing. However, there are many particularities in each of the cycles. Also, there is great variation in terms of country performance. See annex for performance of each country around the first Fed easing, but in general Brazil performs better than Mexico, with the exception of the 1998 (Russia, LTCM) and 2024 cycles (fiscal concerns).
Figure 4: MSCI LatAm performance around the first Fed cut
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.; J.P. Morgan

- On aggregate, sectors have a more uniform positive behavior than countries and regions. In the month before the easing, all the sectors have a positive performance, with utilities and energy being in front (7.6% and 7% respectively), while IT and discretionary are lagging (3.1% and 3.2% respectively). In the month of the rate cut, materials is the best performer by far, but energy, financials and utilities also do well. Gains are a lot more subdued in the month following the easing, with healthcare and utilities delivering a negative performance.
Table 6:Sector performance
Source: Bloomberg Finance L.P.; J.P. Morgan

- Full cycle performance for several different markets is typically negative because it encompasses periods of crisis and not the recovery afterwards (once the Fed is on pause). For example, the easing in cycle 3, which took place during the Global Credit Crisis, ended in December 2008, just 3 months after the Lehman debacle. Cycle 4 ended in March 2020, which is right when Covid was taking hold of the world. The one big exception is the latest Fed easing cycle (cycle 5 in the table), where performance is largely positive across assets, with the exception of Brazil which had a mega sell off in 4Q24.

Brazil: The two triggers that are fundamental for the Brazil story remain in place. 1) Easing cycle, which we expect will start in December and will result in 425bp of easing, bringing the Selic to \(10.75\%\) . JPM is way more dovish than markets on that call but inflation is falling, as are inflation expectations. At the same time, the economy is decelerating, with GDP expected to flatten out in 2H. 2) October 2026 elections, which could lead to regime change. However, the narrative was kidnapped by the US imposition of \(50\%\) tariffs on Brazil followed by the application of sanctions on some Supreme Court justices and members of the Executive. The political, economic and financial consequences of those are still uncertain, especially because it seems that there is more to come from the US. Still, it is incredible to see that despite this shock, the BRL continues to trade at a pretty sturdy level, while the IBOV is down only \(1.5\%\) from recent highs, even though foreign inflows have been very weak. Valuations are very undemanding and while earnings are being revised lower, the two triggers mentioned above should go a long way to bringing the market to new record highs.

Mexico: Mexico is undergoing a soft patch and isn't likely to recover soon considering that the US is also decelerating. The main victim has been capex, which has fallen drastically following the 2024 elections, the judicial reform and the tariff melee imposed by the US. For Mexico, where \(80\%\) of exports go to the US, the trade dynamic is more important than anywhere in the region. So all eyes should be on the USMCA renegotiations that will start in October and, in theory, be concluded in July 2026. It remains to be seen if markets will get a glimpse of what is to come for that deal already this year. Beyond that, economic policy management has been supportive of markets, considering that Banxico continues to ease and the fiscal largesse of 2024 is being corrected. All in all, Mexico today is much more of a bottom- up story than a top- down one.

Chile: The market soared in August on the back of two main drivers: 1) Election polls indicating that regime change is a real possibility and 2) increase in lithium prices, which led SQM ( \(15\%\) of MSCI Chile) to rise by almost \(25\%\) . But, beyond that, the easing rate cycle is ongoing and there has been a significant increase in the participation of pension funds and mutual funds in the local equity market. Valuations are a bit richer, with the 12 mo fwd PE moving from \(9.5X\) PE at the start of the year to 12X now, but justified by a positive trend in companies' revenue growth, with expansion exceeding \(7\%\) and \(10\%\) for 2025 and 2026, respectively.

Peru: Political instability is a persistent challenge: in the last decade, six presidents have taken office, some lasting only five days, and three of them are currently in prison. The presidential race still appears quite open, and while the top candidate by vote preference belongs to the right wing of the political spectrum, it is still a low percentage, with only \(9\%\) of the spontaneous vote preference, as the amount of candidates fragments the polls landscape. Valuations is another topic raising concerns for the Peruvian market,

trading at \(12.2\mathrm{xP / E}\) when its 10- year multiple has been \(12.5\mathrm{xP / E}\) , leaving little room for further re/rating. On the macro front, inflation has remained low, and the Central Bank's reserves are high relative to regional standards. The currency has appreciated by approximately \(4\%\) , and the Central Bank has maintained its rates at \(4.5\%\) .

Colombia: Lack of fundamentals prevent us becoming optimistic going forward, despite positive performance this year. The fiscal situation is worsening, with a deficit projected to reach nearly \(7\%\) of GDP, which already led to rating downgrades. Internally, Colombia still has one of the highest monetary policy rates in the region at \(9.25\%\) , and our economic team expects two 25bp cuts, which could bring the rate to \(8.75\%\) by year- end. In addition, valuations are less attractive than they were before, currently at \(8.2\mathrm{xP / E}\) compared to \(6.3\mathrm{xP / E}\) at the beginning of 2025, though the market is still trading below the 10- year average of \(9.9\mathrm{x}\) . Externally, potential tariff threats from President Trump against President Petro on immigration issues may further increase market volatility, while efforts to boost U.S. domestic oil production could lower oil prices, negatively impacting Colombia's currency and fiscal revenues.

Off Index/Argentina: We have a favorable view on Argentina as the country continues to deliver on key issues that were set at the beginning of the Milei administration. Specifically, inflation is falling, growth is picking up, the fiscal deficit was slashed and capital controls were flexibilized. Argentina is entering a key period with two important elections ahead. First, on September 7 is the election at the province of Buenos Aires, when markets will have an idea of the level of support that President Milei enjoys. October 26 is the midterm elections, which could define if the economic progress seen until now will continue to move ahead. Valuations are very attractive and if politics allows, the market is set for a rebound.

FEMSA (Joseph Giordano, N): After a poor earnings print during 2Q, FEMSA saw a sell- off of \(- 13\%\) , on top of some selling leading into the print, reflecting a \(- 24\%\) drop from the peak in mid- May. This sell- off has led FEMSA to perform significant buybacks \((- \$ 200m\) or \(0.7\%\) of market cap) after their print, yet the stock remains at trough valuations of \(5.6x\) vs. its five- year average of \(7.1x\) .

Cemex (Adrian Huerta, OW): Despite the stock's strong performance \((+80\%\) since April \(10^{\mathrm{th}}\) ), we believe there is further upside as the company has begun to deliver on a new cost- saving program and strategic initiatives under the new management that should continue to allow further upside, primarily on positive earnings prints on a still cheap valuation. Positioning on the name also remains relatively light.

Nubank (Yuri Fernandes, OW): We are more bullish with the Brazilian operations, as increasing credit limits and lower rates could be positive for payroll traction. In Mexico, accelerating loans and lower funding costs should allow operation to achieve breakeven this year. Additionally, the company should announce new geographies soon. With positive momentum, NU trades at \(20x\) 26E P/E.

CMPC (Rodolfo Angele, N): In line with our recent downgrade of Chile, we have decreased exposure in the country by removing CMPC from the portfolio as we see downside potential \((- 6\%\) versus our PT), with limited exposure to both of the main upside risks for Chilean equities: elections and higher copper prices. Additionally, we prefer Brazilian names over Chilean within the pulp and paper sector.

Arca Continental (Lucas Ferreira, OW): Considering the attractive entry point in FEMSA and wanting to remain with the same exposure to the consumer space, we've decided to remove Arca Continental, as we have a stronger preference for the other two consumer names already in our portfolio (TBBB: more direct play to the stronger- than- expected consumer environment within the informal space; and KOF: cheaper than AC and trading closer to its trough multiples).

GCC (Adrian Huerta, OW): As the Cemex story has started to take shape, GCC has been trading sideways, on top of a poor 2Q earnings print that led to downwards guidance revisions. Without significant clarity on a near- term catalyst in GCC, we're switching out of GCC into CX given the better and clearer story.

Rumo (Guilherme Mendes, OW): While the stock trades at a discount, we believe there are limited short- term triggers for Rumo, as the company finds itself in a complicated operational moment, with lower market confidence in Rumo's execution. Within the sector, Rumo is also not the most exposed to easing, and we prefer to keep Motiva in our portfolio.

**Banco do Brasil (Yuri Fernandes, N):** We remove Banco do Brasil as 2Q proved to be another challenging quarter for BBAS, marked by deteriorating asset quality, higher provisioning expenses and higher funding costs harming earnings power for the company. Additionally, we expect the recent large deterioration in agribusiness asset quality to weigh on earnings, profitability and dividend payout. While we continue to see BBAS as a good vehicle to play 2026 election optionality, we believe shares could work closer to that time. BBAS trades at 0.7x 2025E BV and 4.3x 2026E earnings.

External drivers have always dictated LatAm markets, but we are approaching the time when local issues will start to weigh more. Specifically, the easing of rates (which we expect for December) and the election polls are gaining importance as time passes. From a local standpoint, one will still need to pay attention to how the US- Brazil relations will unfold in terms of tariffs and sanctions, especially following the decision of former President Bolsonaro's trial, which is expected on September 12. Apart from this, lower Fed rates should boost EM markets this time as EM growth is ahead of US and dollar weakness is the norm. Brazil is the highest beta within EM and should be one of the largest beneficiaries of that move.

The market is getting to a crucial point and we expect upside but with a lot more volatility. The two structural triggers are: 1) Lower rates: We expect the easing cycle to begin with a first cut of 25bps in December, and an additional 400bps of cuts in 2026, leading rates all the way down to \(10.75\%\) . Brazil is the EM market that hiked the most in 2025 and is likely to be the one that eases the most in 2026. Our view for rates is a non- consensus call, rooted in a growth and inflation deceleration, which has been ongoing. Lower rates bodes well for companies but also for the local mutual fund industry, which has been suffering from outflows over the past 2 years. Equity allocation as \(\%\) of total AUM stands at \(7.9\%\) , which is close to a record low. 2) 2026 elections offer the optionality for a regime change. On one side is President Lula, who has vowed to seek re- election if in good health. On the other side are several state governors, including Tarcisio de Freitas from São Paulo. They are all popular in their states and have a liberal economic framework. Former President Bolsonaro is not allowed to run but the question remains whether anyone from his family will. For all that, there is still uncertainty over who the candidates will be on the right, an issue that the market is anxious about. Beyond these two drivers, the shadow of the US is still permeating Brazilian market prices. It will be important to see if there are more tariffs or sanctions coming up and how both Brazil and the US will deal with those.

2Q25 earnings season was better than expected with earnings growing by \(35\% y / y\) in local currency and \(50\%\) of the companies under our coverage beating expectations. However, guidance for the second half was not encouraging, considering the negative impact of high rates and weaker growth. That has dimmed hopes around potential upward earnings revisions. The 12 mo fwd PE is at \(8.0x\) , which is 1SD below the average. We continue to like domestic sectors, such as financials, industrials and utilities. Within our portfolio, we removed Banco do Brasil given the deterioration of asset quality and included Nubank rooted on lower rates and increasing credit limits in Brazil.

The Chilean market has kept a strong performance, up more than \(11\%\) in the last month. The support has come on the back of two main fronts: 1) presidential polls favoring the candidate with the most orthodox economic program ahead of November elections, and 2) a rebound in SQMs stock, which weights \(15\%\) of MSCI Chile, following the global rebound in lithium prices. On the economic front, the July inflation report delivered an unexpected surprise, with both headline and core CPI figures exceeding expectations by 20bp relative to our forecast. While this single report is not enough to change our forecast for a new 25bp policy rate cut in September, it does make such a move contingent on the August CPI report. On another front, the CB agreed to initiate a program for the accumulation of international reserves of up to US\\$25mn daily for a period of 3 years. The measure is part of a financial management strategy aimed at gradually replacing part of the existing foreign currency credit lines with CBC's own international reserves. This will be done without altering the current total level of international liquidity. Thus, the program does not seek to modify financial conditions or affect the behavior of the foreign exchange market, but rather to strengthen the management of international reserves as part of the financial stability mandate. The policy decision was made some months earlier than what we had anticipated, as we had considered the CBC implementing a new program once the policy rate reached the neutral range.

We remain comfortable with a Neutral rating on Chile, as we see positive drivers but limited room for further multiple re- rating in the short- term. When we downgraded Chile from OW to Neutral in late May, one of the reasons was the increased volatility we were seeing on the political front. After a period of increased uncertainty after the communist party winning the left- wing primary (more details here), polls are now suggesting increased momentum of the right- wing and a likely victory of Kast in second round. The orthodox economic policies that are being proposed by the Republican candidate would likely continue to generate support for the market. Nonetheless, at almost 12x P/E, the room for further re- rating ahead of the elections seems limited, in our view. There are uncertainties, like the composition of congress, that will be hard to predict before the election (November 16th) that in our view will also cap market performance for now.

In line with our recent downgrade of Chile to Neutral, we are removing CMPC from the portfolio as there is only \(3\%\) upside to our target price and it's less exposed to the scenario of a potential positive surprise on the local elections and/or a higher than anticipated copper price, two of the upside risks we have flagged in our downgrade. We are keeping exposure to: Falabella (OW, Nicolas Larrain), our analyst's top pick in the retail sector, as we believe it has a strong domestic exposure, which we like in the current context. Itau Chile (OW, Yuri Fernandes), as our preferred bank given discounted valuation versus larger peers, LTM (OW, Guilherme Mendes) as we continue to see strong operating trends looking forward and SQM (N, Lucas Ferreira) given its extremely competitive exposure to the long term trends of lithium.

Mexico's economic landscape is shaped by several distinctive drivers that have evolved over recent months, where we'd highlight JPM upgraded FY25 GDP growth forecast from \(- 0.9\%\) in late April to \(+1.0\%\) today. This positive shift has been further bolstered by enhanced fiscal policies, including better tax collection, reduced government spending, and better management of PEMEX, which have contributed to a reduction in the fiscal deficit from \(5.7\%\) to a number close to the government's goal of \(4\%\) of GDP. Additionally, Mexico's strategic positioning within North America's supply chain has been reinforced, with its share of total U.S. imports rising to \(15\%\) from \(13.5\%\) at the onset of the trade war, while granting Mexico specific exemptions in the trade war. Furthermore, the stability of the peso, despite lower remittances and immigration risks, alongside the potential alignment of U.S. trade policies with Mexico's nearshoring potential, serves as catalysts for a more optimistic outlook in the future.

The future performance of Mexico's equity market is influenced by a combination of geopolitical and economic factors, with the ongoing renegotiation of the USMCA as the most significant catalyst — presenting both risks and opportunities, with the potential (our base case) for a more favorable outcome for Mexico on a still bumpy path ahead. The postponement of new tariffs by President Trump, including a \(30\%\) tariff threat on non- USMCA compliant imports, has alleviated immediate concerns, allowing Mexico to demonstrate progress in addressing U.S. objectives related to drug trafficking, illegal immigration, and corruption. Additionally, Mexico's equity performance (+31%) YTD in USDs) has been increasingly driven by idiosyncratic factors, with mid- cap companies such as Alsea, Chedraui, Gentera, Volaris, Nemak, and Danhos posting relevant growth throughout the year. The market's valuation remains at 12x and one standard deviation below its historical average of \(- 14 - 15x\) , with the potential to re- rate once uncertainties are addressed, supported by light investor positioning. After the 2Q earnings season, earnings growth for Mexico's equity market remained largely in line with expectations, with adjusted earnings growth for FY25 now projected at \(+6\%\) year- over- year, reflecting a slight increase of \(+0.8\mathrm{p.p}\) . since the start of the earnings season.

We continue to play Mexico through a bottom- up lens and defensive positioning, favoring companies with low earnings risk. We're making two switches to our portfolio, adding FEMSA and removing Arca Continental, considering the former's recent sell- off due to a poor earnings print, which has led to some significant share buybacks (0.7% of market cap during July) and an attractive entry point for the name, trading at all- time lows on an EV/EBITDA basis (5.6x vs. 5Y avg. of 7.1x). We've also rotated out of GCC into Cemex, considering the latter has begun to execute on its new cost- saving and strategic initiatives under a new management team, and despite the \(+80\%\) rally from its trough, valuations remain cheap. The rest of the portfolio and our sector picks remain unchanged. As noted last quarter, although we raised Communication Services to N, we saw no compelling bottom- up trades within our sector sample, which, after posting an 11% total return and outperforming nearly all sectors since our last KTR, we still like the sector's defensiveness but don't view any convincing entry points within our sample today.

MSCI Peru is up \(28\%\) YTD, slightly surpassing Latin America's performance at \(26\%\) . In our view, despite macroeconomic improvements, political volatility remains a significant headwind. President Dina Boluarte's approval rating stands at less than \(4\%\) according to IPE (Instituto de Estudios Peruanos), and with over 50 presidential pre- candidates, political uncertainty is still significant. Moreover, one of the frontrunners in recent polls lacks prior political experience, having previously worked in comedy and impersonating political figures. Nonetheless, the political front has some favorable developments: the introduction of a bicameral system in Peru is expected to enhance stability, as the legislative power will transition from a single chamber of 130 members to a bicameral structure with 130 deputies and 60 senators. In terms of security, social discontent has become more pronounced, rising from 19 points in 2023 to 28 points in the IPSOS survey of July as a priority concern for the Peruvian public. This discontent is partly attributed to illegal mining in Pataz, which \(78\%\) of the population views as a threat to national security. From a macroeconomic perspective, inflation has remained low, and the Central Bank's reserves are high relative to regional standards. The currency has appreciated by approximately \(4\%\) , and the Central Bank has maintained its rates at \(4.5\%\) . Our economists forecast a 25 bp cut in September, which would bring the rate down to \(4.25\%\) by year- end.

We maintain our UW position in our LatAm portfolio, as the uncertain political environment remains and valuation multiples are tight. Political instability in Peru is a persistent challenge: in the last decade, six presidents have taken office, some lasting only five days, and three of them are currently in prison. As mentioned above, the presidential race still appears quite open, and while the top candidate by vote preference belongs to the right wing of the political spectrum, it is still a low percentage, with only \(9\%\) of the spontaneous vote preference, as the amount of candidates fragment the polls landscape. Valuations is another topic raising concerns for the Peruvian market, trading at \(12.2x\) P/E when its 10- year multiple has been \(12.5x\) P/E, leaving little room for further re/rating. On the other hand, MSCI LatAm is trading at \(9.4x\) P/E, compared to its 10- year average of \(11.4x\) P/E, offering greater upside for the region.

We keep IFS (OW, Yuri Fernandes) as our only Peruvian stock in our LatAm portfolio. We view the IFS story positively given the overall positive secular trends in Peru - demographic bonus, high real ROEs, and underpenetrated financial market. Moreover, we believe the current valuation reflects political and asset quality risks and that the valuation gap vs. its main peers is unjustified, hence our Overweight rating.

Distinctive country driversColombia has been the best performer in LatAm YTD, delivering a return of over 40. However, with no strong fundamental drivers in sight and a tightening market, we believe other countries may outperform, leading us to maintain an underweight rating for Colombia. Although polls suggest a potential policy shift in the 2026 presidential elections, the country's fiscal situation has deteriorated markedly. The fiscal deficit is widening above \(7\%\) due to increased spending, prompting S&P to downgrade Colombia to BB, two notches below investment grade with a negative outlook, and a Moody's rating of Baa3, the lowest in the investment-grade segment. Furthermore, the murder of former candidate and polling leader Miguel Uribe has introduced additional political and security uncertainty. These factors, combined with year-to-date performance and valuations nearer to historical averages, indicate limited potential for sustained growth in the equity market.

Factors driving future performanceAlthough investor interest in Colombian equities has been higher this year, several factors indicate that this momentum may not continue for the remainder of the year. A widening fiscal deficit, deteriorating credit ratings, and political uncertainty suggest that the negative drivers outweigh the positives. Internally, Colombia still has one of the highest monetary policy rates in the region at \(9.25\%\) , and our economic team expects two 25bp cuts, which could bring the rate to \(8.75\%\) by year- end. In addition, valuations are less attractive than they were before, currently at \(8.2x\) P/E compared to \(6.3x\) P/E at the beginning of 2025, though the market is still trading below the 10- year average of \(9.9x\) . Externally, potential tariff threats from President Trump against President Petro on immigration issues may further increase market volatility, while efforts to boost U.S. domestic oil production could lower oil prices, negatively impacting Colombia's currency and fiscal revenues.

Argentina has been on the weak side of performance this year, declining \(18\%\) YTD. The surprising part of the underperformance is that the government's macro program implementation remains on track and economic data has been supportive. On this front, July CPI printed at \(1.9\%\) , a tad above our expectation and market consensus \((1.8\%)\) . Despite the \(7.5\%\) average FX depreciation on the month, the headline print saw a modest acceleration from the prior month, yet remained well below the \(2.4\%\) monthly average observed through June. On an over- year- ago basis, the 12- month rate came further down to \(36.6\%\) , from \(39.4\%\) in June. Additionally, the IMF Board approved the first review of the program, enabling a disbursement of about US\$2.0bn. The IMF statement emphasized that tight monetary conditions should continue to support disinflation and the re- monetization process underway.

Argentina's macroeconomic outlook remains robust and valuations are back at the bottom of LatAm. As the nation approaches the mid- term election cycle, politics are at the forefront, with regional elections leading up to the national election on October 26th. A key event is the Province of Buenos Aires election on September 7th, where the alliance between Milei's LLA and PRO could lead to a victory, enhancing prospects for the administration in October. Meanwhile, macroeconomic indicators show a promising turnaround, with significant growth in real economic activity and real credit, projecting a GDP growth of \(5.3\%\) year- over- year in 2025. Inflation is expected to remain low, supported by strong regime credibility and fiscal surplus. The current account deficit is anticipated to narrow due to lower import growth and a more depreciated exchange rate. The policy focus is on bolstering reserves and reducing inflation during the election cycle. Polls indicate the ruling party is poised to perform well in the elections, with economic recovery boosting confidence. In terms of valuations, at the beginning of the year MSCI Argentina was trading at 12M fw P/E multiple of slightly above 10x, with a premium to LatAm. The weak relative performance YTD implies that the multiple has de- rated to only \(7.7x\) earnings, sitting at the bottom of the table of LatAm countries (even below Colombia at \(8.4x\) ) and at a discount of \(20\%\) to the average of the region. In our view, this reflects an attractive entry point into the growth story of Argentina.

Top picks continue to be Galicia (OW, Yuri Fernandes) and Vista (OW, Rodolfo Angele). We like Galicia as a way to play the macro normalization and reactivation of loan demand in Argentina. Our financials team believes that if the macroeconomic normalization continues moving in the right direction and loan demand reactivates, banks could further re- rate towards \(\sim 3x\) P/BV multiples they reached under the Macri administration. Regarding Vista, it remains our Oil & Gas team's preferred way to play the Vaca Muerta theme, offering a simpler profile compared to its peers. The company is primarily focused on oil and has demonstrated strong production growth, effective execution, and upward guidance revisions).

Our LatAm model portfolio is a vehicle to express our strategy views on regional equity markets, sectors, and stocks. This portfolio will normally include stocks that will be constructed relative to the MSCI EM Latin America Index and will be updated on a regular basis through our LatAm Key Trades publication. The portfolio is driven primarily by our fundamental analyst views, and we use our analysts' published company valuation and estimates to support inclusion, but a strategy overlay is incorporated, and hence the published strategy may on occasion differ from analyst views. Analyst ratings are driven by company attractiveness relative to their sector coverage, whereas we take a regional LatAm view. The portfolio can include (1) non- Latin America listed stocks, to the extent the region is a significant company driver, and (2) stocks not currently covered by JPM analysts, to the extent these are heavily weighted MSCI Latin America Index companies, though these companies must always be incorporated at a neutral relative weighting so as to express no strategy or fundamental view. The LatAm model portfolio is usually updated and modified through our LatAm Key Trades publication as well as occasionally in other strategy publications. Please see the publication on www.jpmorganmarkets.com for further information, including important disclosures.
This portfolio has been run since November 2007. Portfolio changes are implemented on the day of the "LatAm Key Trades and Risks" publication.
